verses.text: Then Joshua gathered all the tribes of Israel to Shechem and called for the elders of Israel, their heads, their judges, and their officers; and they presented themselves before God.
verses.comment: Shechem is a recurring covenant site (Gen. 35:4; Josh. 8:33).

verses.text: Joshua said to all the people, 'Thus says the LORD, the God of Israel, "Long ago your fathers lived beyond the Euphrates, Terah, the father of Abraham and of Nahor; and they served other gods."'
verses.comment: Starting a recitation of Israel's history; 'beyond the River' refers to the Euphrates.

verses.text: "Then I took your father Abraham from beyond the River and led him through all the land of Canaan, and multiplied his offspring and gave him Isaac."
verses.comment: 'Offspring' is literal for 'seed'; name is Isaac (Gen. 21:2–3).

verses.text: "And to Isaac I gave Jacob and Esau. I gave Esau the hill country of Seir to possess, but Jacob and his children went down into Egypt."
verses.comment: Mentioning Esau's separate territory in Seir (Gen. 36:8).

verses.text: "Then I sent Moses and Aaron, and I plagued Egypt with what I did in its midst; and afterward I brought you out."
verses.comment: Refers to the plagues and Exodus (Ex. 7:1–5).

verses.text: "And I brought your fathers out of Egypt, and you came to the sea. The Egyptians pursued your fathers with chariots and horsemen to the Red Sea."
verses.comment: Red Sea; literal: 'Sea of Reeds' (Ex. 14:9).

verses.text: "And when they cried out to the LORD, He put darkness between you and the Egyptians, and brought the sea upon them and covered them. Your eyes saw what I did in Egypt. And you lived in the wilderness a long time."
verses.comment: 'A long time' refers to the 40 years in the wilderness.

verses.text: "Then I brought you to the land of the Amorites, who lived beyond the Jordan. They fought with you, and I gave them into your hand. You took possession of their land, and I destroyed them before you."
verses.comment: Referring to victories over Sihon and Og (Num. 21:21–35).

verses.text: "Then Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab, arose and fought against Israel. He sent and invited Balaam the son of Beor to curse you."
verses.comment: Refers to the attempted curse by Balaam (Num. 22).

verses.text: "But I would not listen to Balaam. Instead, he blessed you, so I delivered you from his hand."
verses.comment: Balaam could not curse the Israelites; God overruled him (Num. 23–24).

verses.text: "And you crossed over the Jordan and came to Jericho. The men of Jericho fought against you, and also the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Girgashites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites; and I gave them into your hand."
verses.comment: Recap of the initial conquest (Josh. 3, 6).

verses.text: "And I sent the hornet before you, which drove them out from before you, the two kings of the Amorites; it was not by your sword or by your bow."
verses.comment: 'Hornet' likely a symbol of terror or panic sent by God.

verses.text: "And I gave you a land which you had not labored for, and cities which you had not built, and you live in them. You eat from vineyards and olive groves that you did not plant."
verses.comment: Echoes the Deuteronomic promise (Deut. 6:10–11).

verses.text: "Now therefore fear the LORD and serve Him in sincerity and truth. Put away the gods which your fathers served beyond the River and in Egypt, and serve the LORD."
verses.comment: 'Serve' can mean worship; call to exclusive loyalty to YHWH.

verses.text: "And if it seems evil to you to serve the LORD, choose this day whom you will serve, whether the gods which your fathers served beyond the River, or the gods of the Amorites in whose land you live. But as for me and my house, we will serve the LORD."
verses.comment: Famous affirmation; 'choose this day' is an imperative.

verses.text: Then the people answered, 'Far be it from us to forsake the LORD to serve other gods,
verses.comment: People now formally affirm monotheism.

verses.text: 'for it is the LORD our God who brought us and our fathers up out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of slavery, and who did those great signs in our sight and preserved us all the way that we went, and among all the peoples through whom we passed."
verses.comment: Refers to Exodus, 'house of slavery' as in Exodus; 'preserved' as in Deut. 6:22–23.

verses.text: "And the LORD drove out from before us all the peoples, even the Amorites who lived in the land. Therefore we also will serve the LORD, for He is our God.'
verses.comment: Amorites often stand for all Canaanite peoples.

verses.text: But Joshua said to the people, 'You are not able to serve the LORD, for He is a holy God. He is a jealous God. He will not forgive your transgressions or your sins,"
verses.comment: Not 'cannot', but 'are not able'; expressing God's particular holiness and jealousy.

verses.text: "If you forsake the LORD and serve foreign gods, then He will turn and do you harm and consume you, after He has done you good.'
verses.comment: Condition: consequences for apostasy.

verses.text: And the people said to Joshua, 'No, but we will serve the LORD.'
verses.comment: A renewed declaration of intent.

verses.text: Joshua said to the people, 'You are witnesses against yourselves that you have chosen the LORD, to serve Him.' They said, 'We are witnesses.'
verses.comment: Witness language as covenant ratification.

verses.text: 'Now therefore put away the foreign gods which are among you, and incline your heart to the LORD, the God of Israel.'
verses.comment: Implies some 'gods' still present among the people.

verses.text: And the people said to Joshua, 'The LORD our God we will serve, and His voice we will obey.'
verses.comment: Echoes Sinai covenant response.

verses.text: So Joshua made a covenant with the people that day, and set them a statute and an ordinance in Shechem.
verses.comment: 'Statute and ordinance' is a formula for covenant law.

verses.text: Joshua wrote these words in the Book of the Law of God. And he took a large stone and set it up there under the oak that was by the sanctuary of the LORD.
verses.comment: Ceremonial stone as witness; possibly a different 'oak' than Gen. 35.

verses.text: And Joshua said to all the people, 'See, this stone will be a witness against us, for it has heard all the words of the LORD which He spoke to us. Therefore it shall be a witness against you, lest you deny your God.'
verses.comment: Stone as silent witness (cf. Gen. 31:48). Personification.

verses.text: So Joshua let the people depart, each to his own inheritance.
verses.comment: Men return to their allotted lands.

verses.text: After these things Joshua the son of Nun, the servant of the LORD, died, being one hundred and ten years old.
verses.comment: The same age as Joseph at his death (Gen. 50:26).

verses.text: They buried him within the boundaries of his inheritance at Timnath-serah, which is in the hill country of Ephraim, north of Mount Gaash.
verses.comment: Coordinates with his earlier inheritance (Josh. 19:50).

verses.text: Israel served the LORD all the days of Joshua, and all the days of the elders who outlived Joshua and had known all the work that the LORD did for Israel.
verses.comment: Set up for the period of the Judges.

verses.text: They buried the bones of Joseph, which the people of Israel brought up out of Egypt, at Shechem, in the piece of land that Jacob bought from the sons of Hamor, the father of Shechem, for a hundred pieces of silver. It became an inheritance of the descendants of Joseph.
verses.comment: 'A hundred pieces of silver' literal 'qesitah'; land and bones fulfill Jacob and Joseph's wishes.

verses.text: And Eleazar the son of Aaron died; and they buried him at Gibeah, the town of his son Phinehas, which was given him in the hill country of Ephraim.
verses.comment: 'Gibeah' here is not the same as Benjamin's Gibeah. Phinehas was the high priest's successor.
